body:
It seems to be an interaction with `to_iterator`. If I improve on `to_iterator` this issue goes away: ~https://psalm.dev/r/d727943d80~. Edit: meant this link: https://psalm.dev/r/391e16838b.

I'm closing the issue, but if anyone has any idea how to convey to the psalm that since it's an `array` that the key type mis-match is a-okay that would be helpful.
@morrisonlevi reopening as there's definitely a bug here: https://psalm.dev/r/5efaab0087
You can also clean up your example slightly: https://psalm.dev/r/13748defd1

Thanks for the fix!

The suggestion for my example isn't quite right, I think, because the keys of a generic `iterable` can definitely be different from `array-key`. For instance, it is somewhat common for a `zip(['a' => 3, 'b' => 4], [1, 2])` to yield keys that look like `['a', 0]` and `['b', 1]`. In other words, they are arrays, which is not permitted for `array-key`.

However, if a parameter `$p` is an `iterable<Key, Element>` and I do `is_array($p)` then the type of `Key` is `array-key` without any loss of information. I have no idea how to actually formulate this. Should I open a different issue?
@morrisonlevi that was a bug, fixed in 9878613 and f33d626

issue.title: fix some iterator stubs

labels.name: release:fix
labels.description: The PR will be included in 'Fixes' section of the release notes

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
This fixes some iterator stubs, directly inspired from https://github.com/phpstan/phpstan-src/pull/796

@weirdan can you review this? In particular, I was not sure if I should have used @template-covariant somewhere
